title: RS22401
content: Money laundering in federal criminal law involves various types of laundering under different jurisdictional conditions, outlawing financial transactions related to proceeds from specified unlawful activities with the intent to promote further crimes. Money laundering in federal criminal law, also known as SUA, involves financial transactions with the intent to promote predicate offenses, evade taxation, conceal proceeds, or avoid reporting requirements. It covers international transportation or transmission of funds with similar intentions and also includes undercover investigations. The defendant believes the financial transactions involve proceeds of a predicate offense to promote, conceal ownership, or avoid reporting requirements. Section 1956's crimes are related to predicate offenses, including state, foreign, and federal crimes. The proscribed transactions must promote a predicate offense and involve proceeds of a predicate offense. State crimes listed include RICO predicate offenses like murder, kidnapping, gambling, and drug dealing. The list of foreign crimes recognized as Section 1956 predicate offenses is more extensive than the list of state crimes, covering extraditable offenses. Federal predicate offenses include offenses like interstate kidnapping, theft of funds from federally supported programs, and bank robbery. The RICO predicates for money laundering include theft of funds from federally supported programs, bank robbery, bribery, mail fraud, wire fraud, and federal crimes of terrorism. Conviction of a money laundering offense can result in prison terms, fines, restitution, confiscation, and civil penalties. Violation of Section 1956 can lead to imprisonment for up to 20 years, supervised release for up to three years, and civil penalties. Violators of Section 1956 face a civil penalty of up to $10,000 or the value of the property involved. Confiscation can occur for proceeds of predicate offenses or property involved in money laundering. Section 1957 criminalizes transactions tainted by the origin of the property. Section 1957 covers monetary transactions involving criminally derived property valued at over $10,000, committed in the US or by a US national abroad. Violation or conspiracy to violate this section is punishable by up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000. Section 1957 punishes monetary transactions involving criminally derived property valued over $10,000 with fines up to $250,000 or twice the amount involved. Violators may face civil penalties and property confiscation. The Travel Act penalizes interstate travel with intent to distribute proceeds of unlawful activities or promote such offenses. The Travel Act prohibits interstate travel to promote unlawful activities or commit violent acts. Violating the Act can result in imprisonment for up to five years and fines up to $250,000. Offenders may also face supervised release for up to three years. The Travel Act prohibits interstate travel to promote unlawful activities or commit violent acts, with penalties of up to five years in prison and fines up to $250,000. Offenders may also face supervised release for up to three years. Property associated with a violation of Section 1952 is not subject to confiscation solely by virtue of that fact, although it may be confiscated by operation of the laws governing predicate offenses or money laundering provisions. Section 5322 penalizes willful violation of monetary transaction reporting requirements under Title 31 of the United States Code. Section 5322 penalizes willful violation of monetary transaction reporting requirements under Title 31 of the United States Code, including suspicious transaction reports, special measures record keeping, cash transaction reports, and reports of cash transactions involving $10,000 or more. Simple violations of this section can result in imprisonment for up to five years and fines. Section 5322 of the United States Code penalizes willful violation of monetary transaction reporting requirements, with penalties including imprisonment for up to five years and fines up to $250,000. Violations involving more than $100,000 over a year or committed during another federal crime can result in imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines up to $500,000. Structuring financial transactions to evade reporting requirements is also condemned under Section 5324. The United States Code has sections devoted to transactions involving financial institutions, cash transactions over $10,000, and bringing cash into or out of the country. Violations can result in imprisonment for up to five years and fines up to $250,000, with higher penalties for larger amounts or if committed with another federal offense. Property involved in structuring violations may be confiscated. The Supreme Court ruling in United States v. Bajakajian led to the enactment of the bulk cash smuggling provisions of 31 U.S.C. § 5332, which prohibits carrying or transporting over $10,000 in unreported cash across a U.S. border to evade reporting requirements. This law has been used to prosecute individuals smuggling cash in or out of the country, regardless of whether the money is derived from criminal activity. The offense carries a maximum prison term of five years. Section 1960 prohibits unlicensed money transmitting businesses, including virtual currency like Bitcoin. The offense carries a prison term of up to five years and allows for confiscation of cash and property in place of a fine. The law aims to address issues raised in the Bajakajian case. Section 1960 prohibits unlicensed money transmitting businesses, including virtual currency like Bitcoin, in violation of Department of the Treasury regulations. Offenses under this section can result in imprisonment for up to five years and/or a fine of up to $250,000. Property involved in the violation is subject to civil and criminal forfeiture. All RICO predicate offenses are considered money laundering predicate offenses. Money laundering cases may be prosecuted under RICO shared predicate offense list. RICO prohibits conducting or participating in the affairs of an enterprise engaged in activities affecting interstate commerce through unlawful debt collection or racketeering. Conspiracy to violate RICO's prohibitions is also outlawed, with no overt act requirement for the crime to be complete. Committing a RICO violation results in imprisonment for up to 20 years (or life if a predicate offense carries a life sentence), fines up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations), and seizure of associated property.
